full_text: So we will require people arriving from Great Britain to self-quarantine at home unless they have been fully vaccinated. We will keep this under review and I hope later in the summer we will be able to open up further to the Common Travel Area.
The UK is a third country, a very close neighbour to us. However concerns have been expressed in Great Britain in relation to the variant of concern that is now the dominant strain there.
We will also ease the restrictions on non essential travel for third countries in a broadly similar way, including visitors from the US.

This cert comes into effect at EU level on 1 July and countries are being given time to do this - we will take some of this time, it is important to prepare our systems.  But every week also sees a further 300,000 vaccines doses here and greater levels of protection

By July 19th we will remove the ban on non essential travel. We will also fully implement the EU digital green cert, which means those from an EU country who have been vaccinated, have recovered from Covid or can show a negative PCR test will be able to move freely.
I promised that by the end of May we would give certainty on the way forward for international travel and today we are doing this.

We live on an island - travel and connectivity is important to our economic and social wellbeing.  We need to ensure our important supply chains are resilient. We need to reconnect with our friends and family who live abroad, and welcome tourists back to our beautiful country.

Today is a good day. 2.5m vaccines have been delivered into the arms of Irish people, thanks to the terrific work of the HSE despite the multiple challenges they are facing. We are opening up the country and looking forward to a feeling of normality returning.
https://t.co/NK7R7DLeSg
